I was so torn...really I was..in fact, I asked our waitress if she could surprise me, which she wasn't keen on doing  - even when I said "Really, it's OK...I'd be fine with either"...
A part of me wanted to go crazy adventurous with the Sourvein...hefty bacon, cheddar, blackened chicken tender (not crispy), topped with maple syrup drizzled waffle strips...
The Lair...sounded so up my alley though - love brie, pancetta w/bourbon (my new fave vice) poached pear...

Sourvein ($16) won as she brought up a valid point - I could order the Lar anytime, but not the BOTM.  Decision made!  Due to the overwhelming famous Mac & Cheese reviews...we got this to share, but went with the Lobster Mac & Cheese (of the month) $19..kinda pricey for M&C which included Fresh lobster pieces, pea pods & toasted pretzel roll crumbs...sans cherry tomatoes..
Friend ordered the lunch special (5.3 oz) Motorhead w/fries...$10.

M&C came out pretty quick and served hot!  This was pretty fantastic...elbow noodles were cooked perfectly al dente!  Star for that alone...
Cheese was stringy and creamy at the same time. great flavor..not over powering..
Disappointed in the TINY lobster pieces..you had to fish for it...pea pods were crisp and added a nice texture....We both LOVED this....and could have finished the heaping dish, but needed
room for our burgers....was it worth $19?  No.

Upon boxing our Mac, we waited a good 20 min if not more for our burgers...
My heffer arrives and I can't wait to dive in....I taste the waffle strip first...the maple sweetness was there; a waffle in thin form....I noticed my pretzel bun was hard on one side and not warm....I just wanted to get this bad boy in my mouth...and let me tell you, this was not an easy task ...This puppy was piled high.  I managed to get a small bite after cutting burger in half.  Fries were barely warm, but semi-crisp and a good amount.

Burger was cooked to a perfect 'Medium' as ordered.  Very pink center. Few more small bites and I noticed nothing in/on this burger tasted warm.  I then touched the chicken and center of burger and both felt cool to the touch.  Needless to say this really turned me off..
I was reluctant to eat more & questioned whether it was properly cooked..  

Initially, our waitress came by right after she dropped off our plates to ask how everything was, but at that point I hadn't yet taken a bite.  I commented to my friend about my cold burger and she replied that her's was not warm either, and her bun not soft....When the waitress stopped by again, I asked if the burgers had been sitting because they weren't hot or warm AT ALL.  She replied they had not.  I asked if the burgers are usually served hot or warm, and she firmly stated "They are always served hot."  I expressed my burger temperature & dissatisfaction...Now, this is the part where it gets dicey...
She didn't offer to take my plate right away, she half-heartedly apologized, then finally asked if I wanted to speak to the manager..Yes, yes I do...At that moment, the whole scenario became awkward & unbecoming..

She returns to tell us the Manager is on the phone and can't speak to us, but that if I want, they can make a new burger.  My friend already had her fill and ate a little more than half...didn't want the rest...I told her I wasn't interested in a new burger.  I had lost my appetite and there was no sense in making a new one only for me to bring home and have it sit in my fridge? Another 20 min. & still no manager...

She then tells us she is sorry, offers NO other recourse and says she "Hopes we have a better experience next time". Are you kidding me??  How bout THIS TIME? 
No PARTIAL credit off the bill?  No discount for a 'next time'? And you think I'd come back?
This was so poorly handled..
Hope she gets a better tip..next time.

$50 tab (pre-tip) with NO drinks..water only.  Overpriced (city prices) & shitty customer service...
Thanks, but no thanks..
To add insult to injury...later that day, I felt utterly nauseous..it was all I ate in 24 hrs.
The food is good. Loved the burger, but I've had better. The music tortured my ears for the duration of my stay. Almost total hearing loss is to be expected when visiting.

The atmosphere of Kuma's feels like you're at a metal concert. All the play is hard rock/metal music. I think it was Metallica night when I came because that's what they were playing when I was there. 

The service was really good. We came here around 9pm so no wait and barley anyone there. Our server knew the menu very well and offered to give her suggestions while we were deciding what to order. They've a great beer selection and they also hard liquor as well. 

We ordered the Calamari which was really good. I loved that they fried the cherry peppers as well. The aioli sauce that comes with the calamari compliments very well with the dish.

I ordered the create your own mac n cheese. I choose Bacon and peas. The portion is huge and I couldn't finish half of it. The mac n cheese was very tasty and cheesy. I loved the dish and would order it again. 

If you go there dry the Blueberry Stout beer. One of my favorites!

Almost a five so more like a 4.5.

If you're a fan of great burgers, huge selection of beer and rock music, this is the place for you.  Even if you're a fan of just one of those items, I'd recommend Kuma's anyway.

The plague bringer didn't sound as adventurous as some of the other burgers, but I'm glad I stuck with my gut because I'm such a spice and garlic lover.  You will leave smelling like garlic but it's worth it!  Although grilled jalapenos always taste great, I'm glad Kuma's decided to use raw jalapenos as it gives it more of a kick.  The fries are seasoned perfectly, but weren't as crunchy as I would have liked.  The other reason why this place wasn't a perfect 5 is the bun.  I know you have to have something substantial to withstand the massive, perfectly cooked patty and toppings, but I found it to be a little too doughy for me.  Plus, my bun felt cold.  I would have liked it to be grilled or toasted for a few seconds.  

Ending on 2 positive notes.  1-The service was on point.  Even though the place was packed, I didn't feel rushed and the waitstaff/bartenders were all great!  2-I absolutely love fried pickles and this place's pickles were the best I've had in Chicago thus far.  Thicker sliced, medium breading and not too salty.  Try it!

Burgers are EXTREMLY yummy! however it's quite hard to hold a conversation due to the LOUD rock music playing, I'm not complaining about the music, its just a bit too loud!

Servers are VERY friendly and they know their burgers!

everyone always talks about how they love kuma's corner for burgers.  this new suburban location is the answer to me.   I used to live in the city, I once tried to go to kuma's, but hated that line and the dingy darkness and the loudness blasting heavy metal and I never did get my burger as a result.   So for over ten years I have waited and YES! I have finally arrived!

So the wait still is present but its like just across from woodfield, so I could do a little shopping while I wait my 45-60mins just during lunch hour.  Wow, its still quite loud.   For my understanding of suburban tastes they probably could have saved some cash on the investment.  

But on to the food. It's LEGIT! These burgers are good!  had the "slayer" which is a bunless burger on a serious bed of fries ideal for gorging for one or a filling meal for two.  Ita a flavorful patty, I think chili cooked in beer.  That made me very happy.

I came. I saw and I conquered. Again. I've been to the original Kumas which we all have to agree is outstanding so I was a little worried as to how this one was going to measure up, but it did okay to tell you the truth. I came on a Sunday afternoon to meet up with a girlfriend of mine and it wasn't overly crowded. Inside again, is a little crazy for me with the super loud music. I'm not hating on it, it's just not for me. I come for the food. But I do like their little outdoor patio on the days when it's not scorching hot. Our server was super friendly and attentive and I of course had to start with their legendary mac and cheese which is seriously enough for 4 people to share so the 2 of us couldn't finish it up even though it really is one of the best mac and cheeses on the planet. We did it with proccioto and sundried tomatoes which may be the best combo Kumas can come up with. They also put scallions on top for that extra crunch and green. 

All their burgers are unique and tasty, we got the one with cherry peppers and chipotle mayo and again, huge portion easy enough to share. The fries were good too even though I'm still hoping they bring back the waffle fries because those are better. Sorry, Kumas, that's just the truth. Overall, the place is good, fairly priced for how much food you get and everything was super delicious. If you get your own burger, and you're a girl who can't eat a pound of food at a time, you will probably have leftovers so it's definitely a good place to share.

Definitely nice that they made a Kumas closer to home!

The burgers are really good! You can get any burger and opt for a veggie patty! Great beer selection. The place is usually very crowded and LOUD!! the waiter couldn't even hear what we were saying! It's not just loud but it's heavy metal! I guess that's their thing, so if your ready to sit quietly and enjoy a good burger with loud heavy metal playing the background this place is your go to place!

Definitely an interesting experience as we heard that the burgers were ridiculous and we were not disappointed.  Found the place to be more "suburban" decorated but maintained the music and ambience of the original.  I ordered one of their specials and it was delicious..... It included a full pattie, chicken tender, bacon and syrup and raspberry sauce for extra flavor.  The staff was friendly and knowledgable and we enjoyed our meal... Will be back to sample several other offerings.

Pretty good, but like the other Kuma's location I visited in Chicago -- I wasn't really blown away by the food (just I probably had my expectations set sky high).

What is good about all the Kuma's locations that I've visited is that the meat is high quality. Whether it's the beef patty, chicken, or pork -- it's always tasty, cooked well, and prepared consistently. In this location, the saltiness does seem to be toned down a little, which I like -- consistently across all dishes. The pretzel bun is always fresh with a nice fluffy texture.

My only real issue is that the sauces, condiments, peppers, onions, and other different components that can be added into the burger really don't do much to create a memorable flavor. In fact, sometimes these really detract from enjoying the quality of the nicely cooked patty. With that said though, the flavor combinations in the sandwiches are still enjoyable and do pair well with the fries or chips (which are also a little on the light side for flavor).

If you haven't their Mac & Cheese yet, make sure you do. Slightly firm pasta with a nice creamy cheese sauce, green onions, toasted bread crumbs, and your choice of toppings. A really nice, warm meal for the cold Chicago weather.

Overall, good food but not very memorable for how high ranked this restaurant is on most burger lists for Chicago.

I had my first Kuma's experience here in the burbs and from what friends tell me, the experience is on par with the city from the heavy metal to the tats on everyone's arms and down to the quality of food.

I don't think anyone brings kids to the Kuma's in the city but at this location, people from all walks of life are here despite the loss heavy metal music blaring from the speakers and projected on the wall.

The wait is long but you can put your name down and you'll be texted when your table is ready. My party of 8 got a table in 45 minutes. Good thing you can walk around the other stores in the plaza to pass the time! Starbucks is right next door too. 

I ordered the slayer burger which is their 10 oz patty sitting on a bed of their fries and chili. Andouille sausage too!! This is a massive plate sans bun, but be warned... this is a highly salty meal. 

I preferred the original Kuma burger since the  pretzel bun adds a little sweetness to balance out the burger. I highly recommend the Mac n Cheese which can be ordered with your choice of two toppings like prosciutto and bacon. It's not cheap but definitely can be shared between two to three people depending on your appetite!

I enjoyed my Kuma's experience but in the end, I'm an Au Cheval guy. Either one is a winner but that's just my preference. Find yours and enjoy!

I know, I know...if the music is too loud then you are too old. Maybe I'm old, or maybe I just would like to have a conversation without screaming to my dining partner...first warning: it's loud in there. Second warning: they have some damn delicious burgers! I asked the server to surprise me with something as I just couldn't make up my mind. I was not disappointed - the Led Zepplin was a tasty! Our server was super nice, knew his stuff...just wish I could remember his name. He should be pretty easy to spot with the white crocs :)
(He's the one that pointed them out)
Awesome fries, great burgers cooked perfectly. It feels like your in a cool place in the city. Very hip wait staff, food is great and service is fast.

The service was great and the food was even better

I went here after work with some coworkers. The menu is a little overwhelming with the amount of micro brews they have and their different variations of cheeseburger. 

Our server was great. She made recommendations for beers based on what our personal taste was and when ordering dinner she made multiple warnings about ingredients on the burger which actual help one of the guys change his order. 

The music was not that loud. I had read all the reviews prior to going and had braced myself for the worst. You can have a normal conversion with people at your table with no problem. 

Most of their burgers come on a very taste pretzel roll. One of the guys ordered the Slayer and it was a mountain of food (no bun), so if you order that be prepared. I had the Mastodon which is a BBQ Bacon burger. It was so good. There is a lot of flavor in the beef and they didn't over do it with the BBQ sauce. 

They have a burger that they put chicken and waffles on that won a national award for last year

Kuma's corner in the burbs! Schaumburg to me more exact. It's nicer to go to this location because it is family friendly. All the servers and hostess staff were really nice. The menu is the same as the Logan Square location. They still have a traditional line out the door with  1 hour way. But that's okay because you can walk around to browse at other stores while you wait.

We got seated in less than 1 hour, and had a table of about 8 people. Two of them being toddlers the other two were older kids. Kuma's corner music is blasting heavy metal rock music, which is something you come to accept and deal with because well it's Kuma's corner.

We ordered the traditional Kuma's burger, their lovely macaroni and cheese with broccoli and chicken, and my husband ordered the Slayer.

The Kuma's burger was perfect cooked to a nice medium rare just the way I like it. The Slayer looked like a burger that was killed twice over. It had chili and some spicy sausage it sat on top of piles of french fries. It was an interesting burger with a chili burger flavor. It was good! Of course we love their macaroni and cheese it is amazing with all the cheesy and we enjoyed it.

We like the food which is why we go to Kuma's corner we probably can do without the loud music. But that's how the restaurant is run with a loud atmosphere and that's fine. It just proves to people that their food is that great to go there even if the music doesn't suit us.

I had no idea of what this place was other than that fact that a client had told me they have a pretty good beer list. I walked in to death metal music video and thought "Hey man, this isn't my scene". But I wanted to see their beer list and was blown away at how much awesome craft beer that the had. The place was packed but I found a spot at the bar and had to be picky in what beer's I was going to try as I had driven over and had to drive back to my hotel.  

I was able to try one of DESTIHL's sour beer series "Counter Clockweisse". It was tangy, sour, and mouthwatering. I knew this was going to be both good and bad that I was able to try some great beers but not able to try them all. 

I figured if I was going to have another beer I should put my some food in my stomach to help. I went with the Plague burger, it was a burger that should only be consumed if you are fighting vampires or plan on not making out with anyone as it will contain a ton of garlic. Towards the end of eating it, it became as Lucille Bluth would describe "one hot mess". It was good just falling apart everywhere.

I think this is a pretty good spot to. My only issue is the death metal music which quickly starts to bother my ears after 20 minutes or so, maybe due to that fact that I am getting older but you really should check it out!

The masters of Kuma's Corner have done it again!  There's no stopping them - they are the true insane cutthroat gangstas of the burger realm.  Why would you ever want to get a burger from another joint when you can come to Kuma's (whether you're in city center or chilling in the burbs) and indulge in the most decadent of burgers?  The burgers here at this location are just as fantastic as they are at the original location in the city, but I'd figured just as much.  Something as good as Kuma's wouldn't let location get in the way of the quality food it's serving.

When eating at the Belmont location I'd ordered the Lair of Minotaur burger which totally rocked my socks so for an equally mind-blowing experience at this newest location I ordered the Plague Bringer, which if anything brought some serious heat...but only if you bit into the jalapeños on the burger...which I did and soon regretted afterwards.  Without the jalapeños the burger was phenomenal!  I could have sworn the patty here was even bigger than it was at the original location but that could easily be attributed to my mind playing tricks on me since I haven't eaten at Kuma's for a long while.  Be aware that this burger is totally laced in garlic and however good it may be your mouth will taste like garlic cologne for the next 12+ hours.  

Not only does his location have the Plague Bringer but it also has all of the same burgers thay you've come to know and love from the other locations.  However, at this Kuma's Corner they do have a much more extensive draft selection, many of which are from local and much smaller breweries than some of is heard  of.    What's also interesting is that the bar area was made to look like a concert set-up  with its chromed out pavillion-style light suspenders.  The lights that  were flashing around the bar did seem to come at a cost of de-authenticating the grunge feel of this supposed-to-be  metal bar, but the experience was enjoyable all the same.  

Although I'm still a sucker for the original location and it's coziness it was nice that this location offered such a large space which prevents people from waiting as long as they otherwise would.  I'm not saying that I'm a sadistic creature and like waiting in lines forever, but the original location is what it is - perfection.  The waiters were all perfectly friendly as well!  

Just a sidenote, though: if you want to order alcohol here they'll ask you for two forms of identification due to some Schaumburg ordinance apparently.  So even if you're paying with cash it's advisable to bring your ID and credit card because they can use both to confirm.  Weird, I know.  

This location definitely strived  to achieve the same feel of the Belmont location and although it came close it's not exactly the same.  Despite this, the food is just as good as ever and you won't be let down in the least bit by what you sink your teeth into.  

This puma's over and out so you best get your butt to this new and ever-amazing Kuma's.

Kuma's is going viral. The latest incarnation of this west Belmont institution finds it in Schaumburg. I hope this location isn't cursed because this is where Schlotzsky's withered and died.

What's nice about the location is there is a patio where you can catch some sun if you're not up for the dark bar vibe in the restaurant itself.

It's still Kuma's. The staff is hipster and with tattoos, beards and piercings, but this is the suburbs so there's no crust around their dreadlocks, and their personality is more like a cheerleader. I can live with that.

The menu is a transplant from the original with many popular picks like Neurosis and High on Fire. The burgers are very high quality meat on a delicious pretzel roll. The fixin's are pure fantasy with everything from sriracha mayo to bacon wrapped dates on them. You can get them with their fries or their to-die-for house made potato chips. I always pick those, and I tend to eat them before I take my first bite of burger. If you're beef phobic, they have a high quality bison burger which is a leaner cut for $4 more. The burgers are 10 ounces and range about $14-$15. I had to cut mine in half. If you're more modest in your appetite, I suggest getting a lower priced weekday special burger for about $8 with less meat. 

I ordered a medium rare High on Fire, and it unfortunately came out blue. As I mentioned, I had eaten most of the chips when I noticed that my burger was underdone. "No problem!" said the waiter and they made me a completely new plate, perferctly done, with a fresh stack of chips. I ate those as well. Yay!

The beer selection includes a surprising variety from local microbreweries. Some I didn't even know existed. It was nice to see that our burbs are supporting many new local craft beers. My only beef was that most of the selections were on the hoppy side, even the pilsners and lagers. I prefer Belgian ales as well, and the one they had on tap was smoked with mezcal in it-- honestly a little far afield from my standard choice.

With tax and tip, the two of us had two burgers and four beers which came to $80. There's a price only a hedge fund manager could love! After I left, I found out that this bar had whiskey on tap. Maybe a couple of shots of bourbon would have numbed the shock of that burger and brew tab.

Location:  across from Woodfield Mall in a tourist (and local) center of attention. Ample parking in large mall lot. 
Atmosphere: black and red. Probably looks spooky awesome at night. Played videos of heavy metal groups. Many of which I knew from the MTV era. I feel old. Then there was Brazilian thrash/speed metal. Which is a thing, apparently. Shazam is useful if you miss the title card.
Drinks: looks like a great menu. We didn't take advantage of them, driving two cars (one in shop). 
Servers: passionate about the food and their job. Many are from the other location to establish the brand firmly. 
Food:  beyond good. Full juiced burger with creative toppings and side. I had the mini lunch burger without a bun and it was perfect for me. 
(We had no wait at the end of the business lunch hour)

Oh Kuma's so much hype for years as I anxiously awaited for a location to open in the suburbs......came here the first weekend they were opened. We arrived right at the time they were opening which was perfect. No wait and was seated right away. 

I'm pretty sure I didn't order the right thing. I chose the mac and cheese. Some ingredients I  ordered were missing and we told our server. The manager was kind enough to bring me out the correct order. I found the mac and cheese to be way overpowering and very rich. I brought home both orders of mac and cheese that wound up going in the garbage uneaten.

My husband encouraged me to order a burger and of course I didn't listen. I had a bite of his special burger called the Howler. It had slices of brisket in it. The burger tasted delicious and I knew right then and there I made the wrong decision with my order.

The joint is very loud when you walk with heavy mental music which makes it difficult to hear one another. I honestly feel old saying this, but when I left I had to go home and take something from the headache I had. The husband may go again however I'm not so sure this place is my kind of scene. At least I finally was able to try it!

My in-laws were visiting on a Sunday afternoon and we were looking for a lunch spot - a burger and fry type of place - they like unique stuff so we thought this would be great.

The inside is really nice and we sat outside in their patio which was pleasant and not as noisy. If you don't know, this place plays loud metal music and so if loud music isn't your thing - order take out because you need to try their burgers.

Our server was very friendly... Maybe a bit too talkative, but very attentive.  She gave great selections for beer as some in our group wanted fruitier beer or the closest thing to Miller Lite.  They just serve beer for alcohol, but have an excellent selection of craft beer from all over.

The in-laws ordered The Black Sabbath and the Goatsnake - they both took home leftovers and we're happy with the taste.  My wife is a vegetarian and went with their Mac and cheese, which she said was just "okay."  I ordered the Hatebeak, which is a spicy chicken sandwich, but I was underwhelmed.  Their burgers are huge and this chicken sandwich was tiny with just two small chicken fingers.

It's a cool place, but not first on the list - I'll have to do a burger next time.

The biggest problem with this place is it needs to be twice as large as it is! I've been to the Kuma's locations in the city and in terms of the food quality, this one is just as good. At 4:45 on a Saturday, my friend and I had to wait a half hour for a table. I liked they had special burgers, including a Jamaican themed one with some unusal toppings like fried plantains and marinated flank steak. That's right...flank steak on a burger. God bless America.

I went with the Neurosis: horseradish mayo, sharp cheddar, swiss, caramelized onion, sauteed mushroom..and I addded bacon. The burger was cooked medium, as I asked and the fries were fresh cut.  The bacon could have been done a little more though, it was just too chewy. 

The beer lists are posted on monitors above the bar, which is cool since they can update them as they need to. This place is going to be crowded and loud with rock and roll music, so if you're looking for a quiet place to have a conversation, look somewhere else.

Love me some Kuma's. 

One Saturday night, we wanted burgers and I had just read Aimee's review on this location, so off we headed. With only two of us, it was pretty easy to get a table. No wait. Score! This is seriously the best part considering you usually have to wait an hour + at the Belmont location.

The menu is the same as the original. For an appetizer we got the fried pickles. For dinner, I went with the Absu (my ABSUlute favorite - get it? HA) - tomatillo salas, pepperjack, avocado, queso fresco and fried peppers. My boyfriend went with the Lair of the Minotaur - caramelized onion, pancetta, brie and bourbon poached pear. Welcome to Yumtown! lol that was pretty cheesy.

Their burgers are still huge and delightful. We got a few beers each since there are so many to chose from.  

I don't know what people expect from Kuma's and why I see so many negative reviews. I am never disappointed when I go to the one on Belmont and I was not disappointed at this location either. Yes they play loud heavy metal music, and no it's not very kid friendly, but I go for the f'n burgers and brewskies, nothing else. 

The only thing I didn't like, was the sun blasting our faces off because they have no shades. Might want to work on that Kuma's. But, that doesn't take away from the food OR beer.

I can't wait to go back! It's so convenient now!

Kumas burger. Skid row. Plague bringer. 
Great , greater greatest. 
Excellent quality of meat had lunch special for 8 bucks 5.2 oz of excellent beef. Another menu for lunch  8.00 burgers
Salads are 3.00 they don't tell you but really fresh salad

If I could split reviews I would. 
4 for beer and service/ 3ish for the burger
 
August 13, lunch. 

Solid four for service and knowledge of beers on hand. Every taste our guy brought me was as good or better than the last. Loved it. Wish they offered a flight, but that's the beer nerd in me wanting to try anything I can't get at home. Their colab IPA was stunning, as well as the Arcade Dbl Grapefruit. 

On to the food. (And mind you some of this is really nit picky. )

Fried pickles were good. Super crispy breading (panko maybe) nice pickle inside but it didn't have a pop of flavor. Decent but not mind blowing. 

Chicken tenders where almost perfect. Great buffalo sauce, good size, nice flavor, juicy but an inch into over cooked. Would still get them again. 

Plague burger. Huge, good pretzel bun, garlic that will make me stink for days, perfectly cook...but the burger itself lacked a bit of flavor. Maybe they use a low fat mix or do not season. Would have liked more of a char on the meat. It was overall ok. I have had better, but by far not the worst. 

Fries. Love the idea of fresh cut but these were off. Texture was different and I am not sure how to describe it. I want to say rubbery, but that is not entirely true. Maybe they had been reheated, I don't know. Maybe it is the type of tater they use. Certainly better than frozen. 

Other really small things that no one else would bitch about accept a prick like me. 
Napkins where washed with a scented detergent that lingered after I wiped my hands or mouth on it. Tainted the smells and tastes of what I was eating and drinking. 
Also, beer glasses, both the taster size and the glassware the beer was served in, still had a detergent/bleach smell. It only lingered briefly, but it was enough that I could smell it. Again not something I want to interfere with what the staff and chef are serving me. 

I know this not a very metal review, but f you ;)  

Still a cool joint in a strip mall. Would hit it again and I would recommend.

Kuma's Corner, you had to pick the crazy strip mall across the street from Woodfield, didn't you?  I'd rather parallel park my in a teeny tiny spot behind a cop car, across your original location on Belmont, with tons of cars waiting behind me honking like crazy, with the cop standing there waiting for me to hit his squad car than deal with the crazy people parking in this mall lot...but that's just me. 

But here I was in Schaumburg, hoping that the wait wouldn't be as nuts as your original location.  And gloriously, the trio of us were seated immediately, Saturday at 530pm.  But shortly after that, the wait grew to an hour quickly. 

The atmosphere is like a sleek rock bar. The music is loud. Hard to have a conversation kind  of loud. I was really surprised to see a diaper changing station in the bathroom because I would never take a baby here---it's just too loud.  I would even have to think twice about taking my son here because of the volume, unless they can seat us on the patio. 

Glad to see that the menu is the same as the original location because the jalapeno poppers are awesome.  The filling flavorful and cheesy and the raspberry dipping sauce is the perfect accompaniment for it. 

My burger--the Goatsnake--looked amazing, it was a little more red than I am used to for a Medium, but it was very good and the flavors were delicious--atop the beef patty, there is herbed goat cheese, poblano corn relish, lemon vinaigrette and frizzled onions.  It was a huge burger and I was able to only finish half.  Yay for leftovers!

The craft beer list is great...I just wish the pint glass I was given for my beer wasn't fresh-out-of-the-dishwasher-warm...yuck. 

Service was great...our server (not the person that gave me my beer) was a lot of fun, friendly and helpful.

Kudos, Kuma's! Great entry into the 'burbs. The new place has a nice decorating scheme, with rock show light metallic structures around the bar and elsewhere. Nice band posters abound, a video screen was playing Black Sabbath "videos" from ~1973 when we were there, and the specialty burgers can be had, without the long waits of the original location. 

My son and I enjoyed our visit, but weren't wowed by our burgers. But I always like that trying something different, but haven't found my Kuma's "go to" just yet. Service here is great, and since we got here before the Noon lunch rush, there wasn't much of a wait to be seated, or for our food. I would definitely come back.
Concept is cool. Server and service was OK. Price is average. Burger taste is OK. Fries are salty and soggy. Nothing impressive. I would rather go to Weber Grill and pay few dollars more.

We had a great visit. The food was delicious (no surprise.)  I plowed through a Pantera burger. The burger was cooked perfectly to my order, and the pretzel bun was soft and salty. What really set it apart was the service was exceptional. My sister and I ate with my three-year-old daughter, and the staff went above and beyond to make her comfortable and have a good time. From the hostess getting us a booth with extra elbow room, fun play and interaction from our server (and several other of the servers, too), and a friendly cook that really made her day. Between orders, the cook would make friendly faces, and even brought her a sticker. (Which she loved.) I was a bit put off initially with the loud metal music, dressed in a tie-die and sandals, but I quickly learned that though it may look and sound rough, it's a family place, after all. 
Also, I don't drink, but the beer list was huuuge!

Warning: if you don't like loud heavy metal music, ask to be seated outside!!

The music was super loud and it was difficult to talk to the people I went with. Other than that the food was okay. I got the slayer and it was difficult to eat it all. So much fries but I guess it makes up for no buns. the meat didn't taste that well, had no flavor. 

The customer service was amazing, never had to ask for a refill, they were attentive and super nice. Would definitely go back to try new things there

I've been to Kuma's Corner twice now - once in the city, and once at this location. I didn't like the food at the city location, and so many people suggested I try it and so I decided to try the Schaumburg location. And the second time around, I was still not impressed. I can't remember what I got the first time around, but the second time I got the "Kuma burger" (don't remember the actual name of it, but basically their house burger). Both occasions, I remember the burgers being super dry. The meat didn't have any flavor and wasn't very juicy. I wasn't a fan of the fries either - I think the oil must have been old and their wasn't enough salt on them. Honestly, I think Kuma's is overrated and you can find a better burger elsewhere.

I moved to Chicago 10 years ago..my first 2 years were in the suburbs and made my way to the city for the next 3. Lived about 3 blocks from the original Kumas and fell in love with the joint day one. Metalheads tattoos and big ass burgers.... What more could you ask for? I loved the environment of the original and was there a minimum of twice a week. 

I have been in the suburbs for the past 5 years... My Kumas trips went down dramatically... Once every few months. I was beyond excited about this location opening, close to home, same food win win!!! Right? .....wrong...

The food still is great, the the burgers just as good as the original location... The difference is this Kumas has more kids and let's be honest more snobs.. I have been here a lot of times....and the atmosphere is just crap.... It's not the music because I am a metalhead and couldn't be happier to eat a burger and hear Slayer at the same time.

What I don't like is the fact that I go in and see 20 kids..snobby people that look at you cross eyed when they see your tattoos...it's as if they have no idea what they are walking in to. I actually had a couple next to me one night complain about the music......seriously....

Definitely go here for the food... Just put your blinders on to ignore the other crap.

Metal Burger Bar? Sounds awesome- except the place is full of squares who gawk and whisper when real metal heads walk in. Total waste of time if you're looking for a place to hang out and drink with other metal heads. I suppose the underground death and black metal scene are just another novelty to exploit. 

Had a beer and no food. Perhaps the food is good, but the atmosphere is absolute shit. If I want to try it, I'll do take out. Unless I get a group of 20 - 30 metal heads to turn this place on its ass! 

Perhaps the creator of this mini chain meant well, but it certainly reeks of the Modern Day parasitic mall culture making a mockery of any sub culture worth a damn. 

I'll buy my beer from a distributor and hang out with my friends and a BBQ, while spinning Mortuary Drape LPs. I don't need a faulty establishment in some crummy suburb full of self entitled plebs.

If you like Metal Music, this is a great place to eat or have a drink.
They have a great selection of local Brewers' beer.

The Hamburgers are really good, I liked that they have hot-spicy options

Hmmmm well I loved KC on Belmont in the city so I was ecstatic to have one here in the burbs. To my dismay, I wasn't too pleased with this visit. I came here for lunch and was seated right away so I can't really complain about waiting. They were packed though! I can imagine this place at night. And compared to the one in the city, no wait is a super +++! 

Burger: well next time I will order medium. I got medium well and it was way dry to the point where the burger was almost tasteless. Wish the bacon was crispy too but those are all easy fix I guess, next time ask for extra crispy bacon and medium cooked burger. The burger came with chips and those were super good! 

Fries with pulled pork bbq:  it was ok, wish it had more bbq sauce drenched in it but you can always add that on, no biggie. I wasn't crazy about the quality of the pork  could be better. 

Another beef of mine is that the music was way too loud  . 

I will try again because their burgers are amazing. I might have just been having an off taste kinda day.

I guess the cool thing about this visit to Kuma's being my first visit to ANY Kuma's is the fact that my review will be based solely on the merits of this location only and won't be influenced by any trips to other Kuma's Corner. Because there simply aren't any other visits! OK, time to review!

I opted to sit at the bar - I was there on a Tuesday afternoon around 1PM and there were a fair number of people dining. The bartender greeted me promptly and I began to peruse the menu. I have this tendency to leave my reading glasses in the car and was too lazy to go back out in the cold to get them, so my burger choice was somewhat "blind".  The easiest cut to the chase item burger-wise on the menu appeared to be the "Wasp" - a 6oz lunch burger with cheddar cheese and carmelized onions. I went with that and a Sprecher Root Beer. When I went to order the burger, I ordered it my usual medium rare, but came to find out that the lunch offerings are only cooked in three temperatures; rare, medium and well. So rare it was!

Now, the downside with a rare burger is that between the softness of the meat combined with the juiciness of the burger itself, it can make for a mushy meal overall. By the time I was down to my last few bites, the object I was eating was unidentifiable. And with the juices flowing, I had to wipe my chin every now and then with the awkwardly think cloth napkin that comes with the silverware inside.

Now, while it sounds like all I'm doing is complaining, I will say that taste-wise, it was a darn good burger. Got the homemade chips with it - a few more would have been nice, but one thing that I loved about them was that they weren't full of salt like a lot of homemade chips can be. And throughout my visit, the bartender was helpful, friendly and talkative.

Final verdict - good food, good times. I'll be back at this location.

With so many great restaurants in Chicago that exclusively have locations in the city, I was excited to see the burbs were finally gettin a piece of the action. As expected, I saw a bunch of mixed reviews when they first opened. I remember when Kuma's Too first opened up I saw some of the purists say that it just quite wasn't the same...that it was missing that divey atmosphere and that the brand new equipment was lacking the years of built up seasoning and character. Kuma's Schaumburg skeptics took it even further, with some saying that the music selection and volume have been toned down to cater to more of the suburban family crowd.

While I'm sure the atmosphere is the main draw for some people, as long as the food is just as good I'm a happy camper. The menu was exactly the same, so I was eager to put it to the test and try it myself. I've been to the original Kuma's a couple times a while back, but I wasn't sure if I just got sucked into the hype at the time or if it really did stand out as one of the best burgers in Chicago. 

Food: I absolutely loved the vibe of their menu: over the top burgers that each had at least 2 types of meat in it. It's a celebration of everything greasy and fatty...hell yea. They also had some solid mac and cheese and an extensive beer list. 

Fried pickles - Not a huge pickles fan, but deep frying makes everything taste good. The sauce it came with was really tasty too, creamy with a good kick.

Mac and cheese - The mac and cheese is seriously the biggest sleeper on the entire menu. The burgers get all the glory but the mac and cheese here is legit. Two toppings are included but you can load it up with whatever else you want too. We went with bacon, garlic, sun dried tomatoes, and andouille sausage. The cheese sauce wasn't too creamy or overpowering and the toppings were straight up delicious. How could a meat lovers mac and cheese not be good? Also, finally a place that doesn't skimp on the garlic. The flavor definitely came through. Some of the best mac and cheese I've had.

Godhammered burger - This was their burger of the month. It pretty much had the most meats out of anything else on the menu, so I def had to get it. The burger consisted of a 10 oz burger patty, pulled pork as a topping, candied bacon, jalapeno slaw, and fried onion strings. Just ridiculous. 

The burger patty was cooked perfectly, and was super juicy and seasoned well. The pulled pork was pretty dry and didn't have too much flavor outside of just plain pork. The candied bacon was fantastic, sweet and salty at its finest. It had an awesome crunch and decent amount of fat too. Obviously the frizzled onions were tasty. You can never lose with those as a topping. The slaw was creamy and gave a little bit of spice to the burger. The pretzel bun was a big disappointment. It was cold and not soft at all. I would've preferred it more toasted with a slightly crunchy outside and warm and soft center. Overall, not a bad burger, but definitely not head and shoulders above some of the other burgers I've eaten.


Service: I'll be honest, the service was pretty terrible while we were here. From the minute we sat down, our server was pretty damn slow the entire night. There were just periods of time when he couldn't be found. 

After ordering, we're pretty sure there was a mix up and they delivered our appetizer to the wrong table. When we asked our server about our missing app, he just shrugged his shoulders and claimed he put the order in. The hell? You could've at least said you'd check to see what happened. He obviously didn't care. 

Then a long ass time passed by and we got all our food at once: the burgers, the mac and cheese, and the missing appetizer. It kinda defeated the purpose of the appetizer since we were hungry as hell that entire time and now we had more food than could fit on the table. 

When our server checked up on us he acted all surprised and even made up some bs remark saying oh look at that, the burgers must've been cooked really quick because it came out at the same time as your app. Cmon man, it's obvious you just put the order in again and they only fried those suckers up a few minutes ago. His nonchalance was bordering straight up laziness and apathy.

Overall, Kuma's in Schaumburg wouldn't be one of the places I'd be running to the next time I'm in the area. I'm sure our crappy service could very well have been an isolated incident, but even just judging purely on food it didn't live up to the hype and doesn't justify the long wait, in my opinion. I do love their creative menu and always changing BOTM, but I still prefer other burgers in the burbs like at DMK or Tracks.

Had a great lunch here today! While checking out at Trader Joe's next door, the cashier recommended Kuma's as the best place around to eat. We looked at the reviews for it on Yelp and *almost* decided against it. But we thought the idea of metal music and awesome burgers was too good to pass up!  We are so glad we came! We got a cozy booth and great, attentive service from our blue-haired waitress. (Can't remember her name but she was fantastic and made the experience even more fun). The music and television shows playing added to the fun atmosphere. 
The dude at Trader Joe's had told us the portions were huge so my daughter and I decided to split a burger. We got the Yob burger and it was tasty.  Couldn't decide between the fries or chips so we got both- and so glad we did!  They were both delicious.  The one burger and two sides were PLENTY for us (although wouldn't have been enough for my husband and son). 
The service and food were on point. My only issue was the prices seemed a bit high. Our burger was $15 and I thought it included a side but we were charged for both the fries and chips. I'd definitely come back next time we are in the area though and recommend it to anyone else.

These people definitely know how to make a good burger. I ordered the black sabbath and I think that might be the smallest burger they have. These burgers are no joke. They come in a big boy pretzel bun with a very thick patty and tons of chips/fries. They also have a ton of unique craft beers and the ambiance was almost pleasant with heavy metal in the background instead of acoustic music at a coffeehouse. Not a light meal for sure but will definitely be back to try some of the other burgers!

I haven't tried the Kuma's Corner in the city yet, but I'm happy to say that I tried this new location in Schaumburg. Way to bring some of the city flavor over to the burbs, Kuma! 

First thoughts about the ambiance: a happy marriage of trendy hipster + heavy metal. There's loud heavy metal / rock music playing with the corresponding music video playing on all the TV screens. We happened to go for a weekday lunch and the weather was REALLY nice, so there were no spots on the patio. We didn't have the luxury to wait (my boo had to get back to work), so we just accepted our booth seats indoors. I'll definitely have to get a seat on the patio next time. It's just such a waste not to enjoy the beautiful weather while you can here.

The Burger of the Month was called Godhammered: 10 oz. beef patty, sharp cheddar, Seattle cider braised pulled pork, honey whiskey candied bacon, jalapeno slaw, and frizzled onions. You can get salad, chips or fries. We got chips with this one. 

We also ordered the lunch sized version of the Plague Bringer Burger: roasted garlic mayo, crushed garlic, housemade hot sauce, jalapenos, tortilla strips, lettuce, tomato and onions. We got the fries with this one. Ask for chipotle mayo as an additional dipping sauce. We alternated between dipping into ketchup and the mayo. I do so love my variety of sauces.

The Plague Bringer Burger was better, in my opinion. I loved the crunch of the tortilla strips, and the balance of the savory beef and sauces with the crisp lettuce and tomato together. I can't wait to try the one in the city to compare. 

I've also heard that the build your own mac n cheese is pretty awesome, but I'll have to order that if I come with a larger group. I saw a plate of that at the table next to us, and it just seemed like it was too much for two people.

We ordered the poppers an appetizer. We ordered the Minotaur Burger in the Metallica Burger.
Jalapeno poppers with a jelly are absolutely delicious and not very hot. Both of the burgers we ordered our ginormous in too big for one person to eat. The fresh cut fries are amazing. Will definitely come back here again!
If you don't like a constant barrage of metal music playing, this is probably not the place for you. But, you'll be missing out on an experience!

I'm a burger fanatic. This is by far my favorite place for burgers. Many different burgers to chose from. I've had about 5 of them and loved them all!
The mac-n-cheese is also great! Big portion and they let you add 2 ingredients. We usually do bacon and corn!
If you love burgers you gotta try these! Either location is phenomenal!

Do you like food? Do you like to rock out? Well then this is the place for you. This metal theme restaurant has amazing food and caters forgoes who love Metallica, Slayer and Pantera (they have burgers named after these bands). 

I had the Slayer which was basically a burger patty on a pile of fries covered with chili, cheese and sausages. This was very yummy but spicy. I even tried a friends order of Mac and Cheese which was also amazing and cheesy. You can choose your own combination of extra ingredients for the Mac and cheese.

Now if you love heavy metal you will love the atmosphere. They play metal music very loudly. So unless you enjoy a loud noisy eating experience you might wanna avoid this place. But then again if you don't like metal you probably wouldn't be drawn to it in the first place. 

So in conclusion: tasty greasy food and loud music. 

ROCK ON!!
A lot of hype, but just a mediocre burger with unusual toppings for $20 a head.  Not a lot of flavor - just a lot of loud music.  Maybe I'm too old.

Stopped here today (1/18/2016) not knowing what to expect.  Well I got an ear-full!  Kuma's is a burger place, but upscale.  Yes they have chicken and pork too, but don't ask for any vegan options they don't have them and never will.  The burgers are 10oz and named for various metal bands.  So you have choices of the Iron Maiden, the Metalica or the Slayer.   The music is loud and while we were there we heard Ghost, Pantera, Black Sabbath, Megadeth and Metalica. 
The burgers were great. Huge, covered in great toppings and juicy.  The fries were also really good. I had the Mastodon but next time I want to try the Slayer.

Don't go if you are looking for a quiet place to eat.
Don't go it you have ever owned a Celine Dion album in your life.

Worst customer service I ever experienced,  managers attitude it was ridiculous. Ether was Mike or Matt can't remember. 
I wanted to have a drink before my party arrives,  they told me I cannot be service until everyone shows up.
Really! 
You lost good customers,  we will never go to your place and I will be sharing this to everyone I know how horrible you are (restaurant manager).

Ok so here's a winded one (but worth it)...

So my husband's best friend works in the Schaumburg area eats there often and raves about it constantly, so last Sunday we decided to make the 45 minute drive from Aurora and let me tell you...it was worth the drive and we can't WAIT to go back this weekend!

We walked in about 30-45 minutes after opening and the place was SLAMMED already! This was a for sure sign that yummy adventures were ahead. We opted not to wait for a table and grabbed the last 2 open bar stools available. As busy as it was, the service at the bar was flawless! Can't remember names, but the guy with the hot wavy man bun, and the gal with beautiful shades of blue/green/turquoise hair streaks...they were on point. I mean, seriously... I've worked in the industry and know how completely overwhelming it can get just 2 of you and a full bar top ordering not just drinks but full meals from start-to-finish, everybody.... But they were 100% on it. Super friendly. Super efficient. Super attentive. Can't say enough good things about the service. Now onto the food...

Apparently I live under a rock and had never heard of the Kuma's in the city (let alone burbs) but this place lives up to every dream you've ever had about downing a phenomenal burger. And those other reviewers complaining about cost? Get outta here with your McD's budget and taste, BARF! No joke, most of our 45 minute drive was re-reading the menu and trying to figure out how the hell we were going to pick which burger to start with. Every single one sounded amazeballs.

We started with fried pickles (ps: I'm from country-folk Tennessee where fried pickles are a favorite/staple and these were the best I'd ever had.) They said the buttermilk batter is made fresh every day... talk about crisp and flavorful, I just about slid off my stool! haha! And the burgers?! Good LORD! I got "The Goatsnake" and my man got "The Slayer". If we had moaned any louder at the ridiculousness of flavors, they probably would've tossed us out on naughty suspicions! haha! And the beer selection is impressive... from tap to bottles. Afterall, nothing compliments a great burger like a great beer. Kuma's is just the total package.

One last note about the music.... Folks, it's a heavy metal themed pub. If you are very uncomfortable with that, and can't convince yourself to block out the tunes long enough to experience a CRAZY delicious meal, then don't go (you old farts)... I'm 34 and grew up in a world where Metallica dominated radio and MTV (videos....remember those, MTV??) whether you liked it or not. I respect the heavy metal genre but it's not my favorite. But I also never cared for the Spice Girls either, but I'd still sit through their songs if it mean't I got to eat a Kuma's burger anyhow, HANDS DOWN. 

Go. Just go. Trust me.

I do not hand out 5 stars very often. But I read some good reviews on Yelp about this place and thought I'd give it a try. Glad I did. 

Our server was Bryan. And he was on top of his game. Very friendly and helped us out since it was our first time. The beer selection is stellar. The food was amazing. I am not really big on jalapeño poppers. But I read some raves on here about them and gave them a try. Amazing. 

The burger I had was the Sourvein. It has won some awards and I now know why. It was the best burger I've ever had. Ever. I would strongly recommend this place. 

While I enjoyed the food and time spent here, there were some things I didn't like. They do not and will not have sports on the TV. So if you're looking for the game. Leave this place for another time. We streamed the hockey game on our phone at the table. So we were good haha. They also play really crappy music. The whole time we were there it sounded like one constant slayer song. Like heavy metal stuff. This isn't really my cup of tea. But I'm not going to dock them any stars because the food and service made up for it.

I've been here twice now, and I have to say that the food is absolutely phenomenal. 

My first visit was on a Friday night, and it was absolutely packed. We were lucky to find a spot at the bar, and admired the selection of beers that were available on draft. My boyfriend and I both love metal music, so we enjoyed the loudness of the place and the music videos they showed on their multiple TVs. On our first visit, our server was a bit impatient with us; she lingered while we decided what to order, and eventually she became impatient with me and said that she'd surprise me. This was a bit off-putting, but she made the right choice! 

I had the Lair of the Minotaur burger - Brie cheese and pear - and there are no words as to how delicious it was. My boyfriend had the Mastodon, which he also loved.

Our second visit was on a Tuesday night. The restaurant was nearly empty, and our server was much better. I tried the Mac and cheese with sausage and peas and - oh. my. God. It was a heaping portion and it was to die for. I'm a bit of a Mac and cheese snob, as it's my favorite food in the world, and it was on point! I was so happy to have leftovers.

Be prepared for a loud environment if you come here. We loved it, and will absolutely be returning.

Went for the first time tonight with my girlfriend and we left happy, stuffed, and satisfied.

Got there around 5:30pm and had to wait about 20 minutes for a table. The place is small, so the wait was expected. They have a texting system and they'll send you a message when your table is ready.

The atmosphere is fun and extremely energetic. Lots of fast pounding metal music.

Once seated, our waitress was friendly and knowledgeable. The beer list is long and good. I ordered the Led Zeppelin burger (bacon, pulled pork, BBQ sauce, cheddar). It was cooked perfectly all the way through, the fries were also delicious. The pretzel bun is a very nice touch.

Kuma's is definitely worth the trip and would highly recommend for a great tasting burger.

Get ready for the heavy metal music when you walk in! The food is amazing. The plague bringer is easily the best burger I have ever had. It has a little spice to it with the jalapeños, yummy roasted garlic mayonnaise and crunchy tortilla strips. The jalapeño poppers are a must. The service exceeded my expectations and I was very impressed. One of my friends has a gluten allergy, and the chef came out to review the ingredients in the burger and make other recommendations. They have a large beer selection to choose from!

I love the burgers been there 4 times now and I keep trying different burgers, they don't handle domestic beers at all so get ready for a rainbow of IPA's, the place is too small though I could see this place being in a larger venue and expanding the rock concert theme. But I like these guys as they stick to there own style of food and staying true to metal.

I live down the street from Kuma's in Chicago yet I've never gone! Although I have heard many great things.
Last night after a bad movie with good company in the suburbs, we decided on Kuma's to satisfy everyone's taste. Beer menus often overwhelm me and the bloody mary sounded good so I ordered that. It was a fantastic mix that was very original! 

Our waitress tempted us with her mac and cheese special w bacon and scallops that made my mouth water but I just had to get the famous burger for my first visit. The meat was fluffy and flavorful and I love that every burger automatically has pretzel bun. This, my friends, was the best burger I've ever had! 

I'm definitely to go to a Kuma's sometime soon to order a mac n cheese!

I kind of feel like Kuma's Corner evolved with my lifestyle. When I was a young, tattooed, pierced jerk who loved Booz and gore and lived fast and hard, I'd come to the OG Kuma's in Avondale and get too drunk on Scrumpy's delicious cider while indulging in burgers and metal, blending in with the bad ass crowd, enduring the long waits for the amazing food and equally bangin' street cred. 

Then life slowed down, my career picked up, I began covering up the tattoos more and more and taking on responsibilities like marriage, dogs, rent, car payments... You know, grown up sh*t. Gone were the days of wasting time at the bar, desperate for a table to open up with a good view of the horror movies blaring across the screens at the bar. So we moved on to Kuma's Lakeview. Larger, quieter, a more reasonable wait to match my more reasonable, logical lifestyle. We'd politely walk past the well groomed businesses of almost-lincoln-park and drive home in our Nissan when it was over.

And now? Now we call Kuma's Schaumburg. We order pickup (who can be bothered to dine in at a restaurant after a tough day at the office?). We drive in our SUV to go pick it up. We tip the hostess. We eat in our living room. We go to bed at a reasonable hour. It's true. And it's sad.

What ISN'T sad is that Kuma's amazingly delicious menu has been maintained throughout. The quality is dead on. The recipes are the same. The burgers are on point. The food is timeless. The staff is polite. All the things that made Kuma's famous and makes Kuma's great are here. I ordered a delicious Sleep burger (a November tradition), and chips, and everything was delicious and traveled well, hot, and neatly. The interior of this place is suburban and sterile and clean. It's comfortable for a restaurant, but admittedly odd for a Kuma's. But still... The burgers is why we began to come, and the burgers are why we keep coming back. Even to the suburbs.

I don't want to think of the next installation of Kuma's just yet. I fear I'll be sitting in a nursing home, wistfully staring out the window wishing the grandkids visited more, when my nice nurse will bring me a Pantera burger, neatly cut up to accommodate my dentures-filled mouth and frail hands. I'll wheel over to my husband, throw up some devil horns, and gum my burger blissfully. It's coming, I'm sure... But I'm not ready yet. So in the interim, a Schaumburg Kuma's doesn't sound so bad, and I will happily return.

From the reviews, it appears I'm the last of my Yelp friends to visit this place.  I don't know what I expected that kept me from checking it out, but I'm glad I finally went.  I looked through the food pictures before I went and the Led Zeppelin caught my eye, so that's what I ordered.  The people I went with ordered the mac & cheese.  It was an insane amount of food for the price.  And one thing that really impressed me is this: the place was busy so we had to wait for a table, but once we sat down and ordered our food arrived quickly and almost too hot to eat.  It couldn't have been fresher!  The burger with pulled pork was delicious and their home made chips were a step above the norm.  The music was none I have in my player, but it was low enough volume-wise that it added kind of a background soundtrack for the place without making it difficult for us to easily carry on a conversation. There was also a varied selection of beers.  In general they've just got everything right.

Absolutely love this place. The heavy metal themed burgers are just great. I have had the Slayer and the the Pantera and was very pleased with both. My girlfriend always gets the bean burgers and she loves those too. I have only ever actually gotten delivery from this place, but the food is always hot and fresh.

Their menu is currently on http://www.kumascorner.com/menu.

Shared a Slayer (a 10oz patty on top of chili fries, grilled onions, peppers, andouille sausage, and Monterey Jack cheese--No bun) and lunch special Kumar burger (the infamous burger on a pretzel bun with an over easy egg, as well as sharp cheddar, lettuce, onion, and tomato). 

The Kumar lunch special version is $10, versus the regular at $14. Not sure what the difference is between the two versions, other than the lunch special is only available in rare/medium/well done and not medium rare or medium well. Make sure that you specifically say that you want the lunch special. They charged us for the regular even though my sister pointed to the lunch menu when she ordered (they do have other burgers on the lunch menu, which is weekdays until 5pm). But they were super nice (and attentive) and changed the price for us. My sister was surprised how nice they were, considering that they are metalheads, speaking as a former metalhead.

Ok on to the food review. We were disappointed with the quality, despite the big portions, and made us miss In-N-Out. The Kumar was not warm, even the bun was cold. My sister ordered it medicine but it was bright red inside. The vegetables on the Kumar looked old. The Kumar was bland, while the Slayer was salty (I had a drink of water nearly after each bite. I liked the Slayer better, but of course it was mostly fries. Still a huge amount of food for the Slayer, so much so that it was hard to fit my leftovers in one box. The Slayer was a little spicy and had a decent amount of sausage. 

Came at 2pm on a Friday and no wait. Music is not my favorite but it's not as loud as I thought although it's still kind of loud, enough to worsen my headache, but not as loud as a concert. 

Glad it's wheelchair accessible unlike its famous Chicago location, so unfortunately, I can't compare the two locations. They have a parking lot in a strip mall (the same one as Nordstrom Rack and the Container Store, but it is closer to the street) with one wheelchair accessible parking space in the lot closest to them. There's more accessible parking in the strip mall at large. 

It's hard to see at first, but it's directly across from the California Pizza Kitchen. Look for a red bear in a window.

Love this place. I recommend the Slayer! However next time I'm definitely gonna split it with someone since the portion size is too big for me. It's probably gonna take me another two days to finish my leftovers. Service is good as well! Never had to ask for water refills, nor did I have to ask for a to-go box. Server was very nice and observant.

I don't know where to start with this review- let's say that I was expecting more than was delivered.

Nothing huge was wrong but I felt that it was quite an underwhelming experience.

The sound system was beyond awful; I am old enough to have attended live performances of many of the bands that were being shown on the TV's and can only conclude that Kuma's is using the crappy built in speakers in the TV rather than a separate amp/speaker system. At the very least- the system that they have isn't suited to the acoustics of the dining area/bar.

Service was slow if friendly early on a Sunday night where it didn't appear to otherwise be terribly busy. We might just have been unlucky enough to arrive at a shift change.

The beer list was extensive with many eclectic selections from small breweries in the area. The food seemed to be tempting but what we got was largely lukewarm/cold without much in the way of character or freshness. I seldom send food back but I was tempted to in this case- I didn't because it was a very late lunch for the two of us and to be honest I would have eaten just about anything at that point.

In spite of this location being open for going on 6 months now, the staff seemed disorganized and not in tune with their surroundings. It seemed to me that the bartenders seemed overly attentive/chatty to the waitresses who just got off their shift and were seated at the bar- this was at the expense of the customers at the bar who were trying all sort of ways to get attention and service.

The bottom line is I felt the concept of being an anti-"Hard Rock Cafe" is great, with the execution at this location being substandard.

I like this location because I think it is the quietest and most "neutral" atmosphere of the three. There seems to be more space, and of course an abundance of parking. The food is just as tasty, and the service has been great! Plus that basil vinaigrette on the salad is so good!!!

LOUD!!! ANGRY!!! DEATH METAL!!!RAAAAWWWRRR!!!! Which is nice if you like Death Metal. I love to give high reviews to hip or newer places and I tried, I really did, but Kuma's failed to impress. The plus points: plenty of parking, nice bearded staff, nice seating-overall good look,. Know that I completely understand the death metal theme with the blaring music...cause you really shouldn't listen to it any other way---I mean it IS Death Metal---and the scary names of the burgers, we had the Embalmed and the Goatsnake. The noise just got annoying (sorry to the metalheads--guess I'm a square) and maybe it was my fault for ordering the Goatsnake with the grilled chicken instead of the whopping , what looked like--a one pound beef patty. The goatsnake was described really well in the menu and the server said lots of people substitute chicken or other choices for beef but in all honesty---it was bland. My husband loved his Embalmed featuring pulled chicken in mole on it. I tasted it but wasnt impressed and his was a beef burger. Also there was a wierd movie on the big screen featuring dead bodies and other nasty stuff.  I will say the basil balsamic was AWESOME and the salad both in looks and freshness was just lovely!! They also offer Sriracha and Choloula sauce which is nice but no amount of sauce livened up my burger.  Everything else was noisy and bla. If you are into this be sure to give it one chance. Maybe it is just square me but I'll go back with a group or something if I have to.

Didn't rally live up to they hype.  The burger as ok but the bun was dry and the condiments were wilted. I have had plenty of $15 burgers and I can assure you that this is not one of them. 

He only plus was Mac and cheese.  It really was amazing. But not worth $14 of amazing. 

My kid has the chicken strips and they were dry (and slightly burnt)

Basically it is a bar with hard metal music.  I will now take some Aspirin and Tums... And pay a $125 bill for four burgers and two beers.  

Go next door to California Kitchen...  Better food.
This place is an unusual gem in the middle of slightly boring Schaumburg. Heavy meal themed with a killer beer menu and heavy food to match. The burgers are incredible, as is the Mac and cheese.

Found out about these from Triple D. This location was much closer to our hotel, and it didn't disappoint! Music was heavy and loud, food was great, and there were so many beers and liquors to choose from. Definitely worth a try. I had the Slayer and it was incredible. I'll be back for the Black Sabbath, YOB, and Mastadon burgers before I leave town

Don't get all the hype over Kumas.  First of all the extremely loud death metal music is absolutely obnoxious.  The menu is basically burgers and Mac and cheese.  I had the Led Zeppelin burger.  It was good but nothing to get excited over.  It was huge  I had to eat it with a knife and fork.  The servers and hostess were very friendly, but that isn't enough to bring me back to Kumas.

Update:
Pretty sure they just increased the price of everything making it not worth. 


Solid burgers lots of drinks. 

The fried pickles are great here. It's not heavy and not over fried to the point where you can't taste the pickle. 

I got their new burger of the month Godflesh. It had bacon wrapped dates, pickled onions, 2 year aged white cheddar, spicy malt aoli. Lots of flavor but it wasn't too consistent because my mouth couldn't handle all that grease and flavor at once. 

I'm honestly not a fan of all these specialty burgers (massive size loaded with topics) but Kuma's hasn't disappointed me yet. They've improved their service since their opening. Attentive waiters, food came out in reasonable time and together.

Kelly & I came here in advance of a comedy show we had tix for last Saturday night.  Anticipating a wait, we arrived about 4:45 on a Saturday afternoon & were seated immediately.  We were stunned since we were expecting long lines for this place on a Saturday afternoon.  This was my second time to this location, having been to the main one in the city, but Kelly's first & she had been warned about the music.  She is not a fan of screaming death metal.  

Kelly & I perused the menu.  Since Kuma's burgers are 10 oz, we decided to split a burger and an entree mac & cheese.  We ordered the Kaijo burger, house chips  & their  bacon  & mushroom mac n cheese.  They came out in about 15 minutes.  We split the dishes as I waited to see Kelly's reaction as she tried both.  The look on her face was pretty much a food-gasm.  She couldn't stop saying OMG to both.  The burger was extremely flavorful, a bit more cooked than we had requested but was awesome.  Their house chips are outstanding as well.  Thin, cooked & salted perfectly for my liking....and even better when used to eat mac & cheese on.  

As far as the mac & cheese, it was fantastic.  Just the right combination of cheeses to pasta, the bacon & shrooms were cooked perfectly.  The bowl they bring it out in is HUGE though.  Be forewarned.  Between the burger & the mac & cheese, we had to take some of the mac n cheese home, but were very sad to throw it out since it wasn't going to last 5+ hrs in a 90 degree car.  

Service was great too.  Our waiter was very knowledgeable, patient, making all kinds of recommendations, checking on us frequently, etc.  

As we left, I asked Kelly for a rating.  She said 4.5 out of 5 (didn't care for SOME of the music).  As a metalhead knowing what I was getting into, I thought the whole experience was awesome.  We look forward to coming back & eating with the senior metalheads at 4:30!

I have visited all three of their locations multiple times and the one in Schaumberg is probably my favorite. My review however is based on my collective experience. 
This place always has a crowd, be it lunch or dinner. However, I have never had to wait for over 30 min to get seated. It's great to see a  new burger to try in their "burger of the month" section. And each of their burgers is so distinctly different from the other in terms of toppings. I have tried many of the crazy ones , including a BOTM which had chicken and waffles on top of the patty. This place is definitely worth a try if you're in for a good burger and beer that is reasonably priced. Their house chips are well seasoned and I recommend you try it.
One of the issues I do have with Kuma's Corner in Chicago ( not Schaumburg) is that although they're open until late, their service gets sloppy and the place gets extremely dirty... sticky tables and chairs, spilled food and drink on the floor which isn't cleaned up, dirty restrooms... and the dark and dingy ambience only adds to it. It's happened on a couple of occasions after which we stopped going there for a late night bite.

Where do I start?

This place is by far my favorite to get a burger. I love the other locations, but they're a bit harder to get to and the wait is longer so the Schaumburg location has made getting a great burger much easier. 

The staff is great and always helpful. Every time we come in the staff is friendly and remembers us. 

They've got a huge beer menu and it's amazing. There's a beer for everyone and every burger. 

Don't go here if you're offended by the occasional satanic imagery or loud heavy metal music. But if you're like me and love that stuff, this place is for you.

I like the music. Like the burgers.

Kuma's corner is a real fun place.  Technically it's not on a corner. It's in a large strip center in Schaumburg. Don't get me wrong I'm glad they opened up in Schaumburg.... 

I see Kuma's as a good Friday night joint.  And we get it it's not the same as the one on Belmont Avenue.

Ok, so kumas corner finally decided to franchise out! Great. So I guess they sold out like the Metallica music they play! How ironic! All kidding aside, they serve the exact same food, but the portions, quality and atmosphere is quite different.

I understand first and foremost how they have to accommodate the suburban demographic, so of course hipsters should probably go to the original one on Belmont or kumas two. The music has also been censored somewhat as to not drive off the customers. Gone are the hard stoner, grindcore, death metal and replaced are: Metallica (later) mastodon (later) the sword (later) and five finger death punch (all) . See where I'm going with this?

I ordered the plague bringer burger and the oven did not heat this fully. It came out lukewarm, and the fries were portioned smaller.

Stick  to kumas corner or kumas two, unless you are already in the area . Either way, it's worth the trip to Belmont!

Admittedly, I set low expectations coming here, because of all the good things I've heard. I really didn't want to be let down. The Chicago locations have been hyped up for several years by friends and co-workers, and I've never had the opportunity to venture out that way.

That said, as soon as this location opened up, I was excited to finally give Kuma's Corner a shot. My wife and I came here for a date night on a Monday evening (9pm) and we were able to get seated immediately.

One thing I loved from the start was that there were no sports stations on the television sets... the ambience was subdued and intimate. I was nervous about how loud the metal music was going to be, but pleasantly surprised that my wife and I could easily carry on a conversation.

What was on the tv screens were various obscure and popular metal music videos.My wife didn't realize I knew so many lyrics to Metallica's "One", a result of several hours of Guitar Hero in my college days.

The burgers... forget about it! Easily the best burgers I've ever had. The price was a little startling at first, but after tasting the combinations of flavors, the value was clear. I had the Slayer, which is basically a bunless chili burger, but don't let my description fool you. It was rich and hearty, and I was thankful for the mountain of fries to offset the savory goodness. Ask for extra "Anger"... ;)

My wife had the Goatsnake and the pairing of goat cheese and lemon vinaigrette was surprising and addictive. This burger is one that is hard to put down between bites and I fought hard to resist having more than just a taste.

In the end, the overall experience lived up to the hype. The service was attentive and patient, there was no wait time (it was late evening), and the food was innovative and beyond my imagination. We will be back to experience the other burgers as well as the well-renowned mac and cheese. Though my wife and I are not the biggest metalheads... For the time we were there, we really wanted to be.

We usually avoid the Woodfield Mall area like the plague but found ourselves there on an unavoidable errand so we were happy to have Kuma's Corner as our reward for suffering through a visit to the mall.

We came at lunchtime on a Saturday and were able to be immediately seated in the bar area at a high-top or outside (only a wait for a regular table but there wasn't a big line or anything). Since it's summer-time and we weren't going home immediately we opted to share an appetizer and a burger so we wouldn't have any leftovers going to waste.  We shared the Jalapeno Poppers stuffed with ground chorizo and cheddar served with a raspberry jam type of dipping sauce.  Wow, were those good...and pricey at $12 (so $2 for each as there were 6 on the platter). They were mighty tasty at least.

For the burger we shared the Goatsnake and it was one of the best burgers I've ever had (I've been on a roll with mighty good burgers lately, for the most part). It was cooked perfectly medium-rare and topped with herbed goat cheese, corn relish, fried onion strings and an amazing Cholula-lemon vinaigrette which really was an absolutely perfect condiment for this burger. Their housemade chips were okay - not amazing, but all right.

They also have a rather extensive beer list so you have plenty of options to pair with your meal.  The service was okay, though a bit awkward since all the high-tops in the bar area are very close together (seriously, there isn't room to walk between if you have others seated at the tables next to you, you'll have to walk around/behind).
